questions.text: Tropical spastic paraparesis is caused by
questions.solution: Ans.: A. Human T-Cell Lymphotropic Virus • This virus causes T-cell leukemia in humans. It also causes an autoimmune disease called tropical spastic paraparesis. • There are two human T-cell lymphotropic virus (HTLV) isolates so far, HTLV-1 and HTLV-2, both of which are associated with leukemias and lymphomas. • HTLV-1 was isolated in 1980 from the cells of a patient with a cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. • Its RNA and proteins are different from those of all other retroviruses. • In addition to cancer, HTLV is the cause of tropical spastic paraparesis, an autoimmune disease in which progressive weakness of the legs occurs. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 328

questions.text: Human papilloma virus is associated with all of the following cancers except
questions.solution: Ans : C. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma • HPV causes skin warts, Laryngeal papilloma, Oral & Conjunctival papilloma. • It also causes condyloma acuminatum (anorectal warts), Plantar warts, Human cervical carcinoma and Cervical intraepithelial neoplasia • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is associated with EBV. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 307

questions.text: Which of the following structures are required in the fluorscent microscope for obtaining the image
questions.solution: Ans: C. Dichroic mirror • In fluorescent microscope, the specimen is illuminated with light of a specific wavelength (or wavelengths) which is absorbed by the fluorophores, causing them to emit light of longer wavelengths (i.e., of a different color than the absorbed light). • The dichroic mirror is chosen to match the spectral excitation and emission characteristics of thefluorophore used to label the specimen Ref: Foundations in Microbiology, 10th Ed, Page No : 68

choices.text: H.influenzae stains are known to produce Beta lactamase
H.influenzae stains are known to have altered penicillin binding proteins
Cefotaxime is easier to administer then ampicilin
Drug of choice for this condition is sulphamethoxazole

questions.text: In a child admitted with hemophilus influenza meningitis. cefotaxime was started instead of ampicilin . which of these is the likely reason for this
questions.solution: Ans.:A. H.influenzae stains are known to produce Beta lactamase • The treatment of choice for meningitis or other serious • systemic infections caused by H. influenzae is ceftriaxone. • From 20% to 30% of H. influenzae type b isolates produce a ?-lactamase that degrades penicillinase-sensitive ?-lactams such as ampicillin but not ceftriaxone. • It is important to institute antibiotic treatment promptly, because the incidence of neurologic sequelae (e.g., subdural empyema) is high. • Untreated H. influenzae meningitis has a fatality rate of approximately 90%. • H. influenzae upper respiratory tract infections, such as otitis media and sinusitis, are treated with either amoxicillin-clavulanate or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 173

questions.text: Reverse transcriptase is a RNA dependent DNA polymerase . Which of these viruses has reverse transcriptase
questions.solution: Ans: B. Hepatitis B Virus • HBV is a member of the hepadnavirus family. It is a 42-nm enveloped virion with an icosahedral nucleocapsid core containing a partially double-stranded circular DNA genome. • The DNA polymerase has both RNA-dependent (reverse transcriptase) and DNA-dependent activity. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 344

questions.text: Filarial stage of adult worms responsible for disease in all of the following except
questions.solution: Ans.: D. Mansonella ozzardi • The adult worms are found in the peritoneal and pleural cavities of humans. • The nonperiodic unsheathed microfilariae are found in the blood. • Culicoides species are the vectors. • Infection does not cause any illness. • Diagnosis is made by demonstrating microfilariae in blood • Ivermectin (single dose 6 mg) is effective in treatment. Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 219

questions.text: Vibrio cholera toxin acts by disrupting which of the following structures
questions.solution: Ans.: C. Zona occludens • Zonula occludens toxin (Zot) is an enterotoxin elaborated by Vibrio cholerae that increases intestinal permeability by interacting with a mammalian cell receptor with subsequent activation of intracellular signaling leading to the disassembly of the intercellular tight junctions. • Zot localizes in the bacterial outer membrane of V. cholerae with subsequent cleavage and secretion of a carboxyl-terminal fragment in the host intestinal milieu. Ref :https://www.jbc.org/content/276/22/19160.full

questions.text: A patient presented with a vesicle on shin. Microscopy of Tzank smear showed giant cells. Causative agent is
questions.solution: Ans: B. Varicella zoster • Four herpesviruses, namely HSV types 1 and 2, VZV, and CMV, induce the formation of multinucleated giant cells, which can be seen microscopically in the lesions. • A rapid presumptive diagnosis can be made from skin lesions by using the Tzanck smear, in which cells from the base of the vesicle are stained with Giemsa stain. • The presence of multinucleated giant cells suggests herpesvirus infection. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 293

questions.text: Phage mediated change in C. diphtheria is which of the following :
questions.solution: Ans. B. Transduction • The toxin is a single polypeptide with two functional domains. • The binding (B) domain mediates binding of the toxin to glycoprotein receptors on the cell membrane. • The active (A) domain possesses enzymatic activity that cleaves nicotinamide from nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and transfers the remaining ADP-ribose to EF-2, thereby inactivating it. • The DNA that codes for diphtheria toxin is part of the DNA of a temperate bacteriophage called beta phage. • During the lysogenic phase of viral growth, the DNA of this virus integrates into the bacterial chromosome and the toxin is synthesized. • Corynebacterium diphtheriae cells that are not lysogenized by this phage do not produce exotoxin and are non-pathogenic. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 143

choices.text: Ingestion of food of contaminated with the egg of larva

questions.text: Stool examination in patient reveals the following finding what is the likely route of infection of this parasite
questions.solution: Ans. A Ingestion of food contaminated with egg of larva • Adult Trichuris worm lives in large intestine. • It resembles a whip. Anterior 3/5th is thin and posterior 2/5th is thick and stout, appearing as handle of a whip. • Egg is triple-shelled, barrel-shaped with a mucus plug at each pole. It is bile-stained and contains an unsegmented ovum. The egg ¬floats in saturated salt solution. • Natural host: Man is the only host. No intermediate host. • Infective form: Embryonated egg containing rhabditiform larva that develops in soil. • Clinical features: Light infection is asymptomatic. In heavy infection, worm may give rise to acute appendicitis, abdominal pain, mucous diarrhea, anemia, prolapse of rectum, and weight loss. • Diagnosis: Finding of characteristic eggs in stool and sigmoidoscopy may show worms hanging from the rectal mucosa. • Treatment: Mebendazole or albendazole. Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 175

questions.text: A patient presented with headache and projectile vomiting along with altered sensorium. The following parasite demonstrated on indian ink staining. What is the likely diagnosis
questions.solution: Ans. A Cryptococcus • Cryptococcus neoformans /European Blastomycosis, • Encapsulated yeast. • Polysaccharide capsule composed of mannose, xylose, and glucuronic acid. • Transmitted by inhalation. • CNS cryptococcosis - Subacute or chronic meningitis and meningoencephalitis • Specimen - CSF, sputum, pus, and brain biopsy tissue. • In India ink preparation of CSF, capsule (clear halo around the yeast cell) can be demonstrated in 25–50% of patients with cryptococcal meningitis. • Amphotericin B is the drug of choice.

questions.text: This is a schematic diagram depicting body structure of which of thehelminths :
questions.solution: Ans. C Brugiamalayi The diagnostic algorithm Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 204

questions.text: 73 A patient comes to your clinic with a complaint of multiple episodes of loose watery stool for 3 days. on probing. Youdiscover that these episodes start after he had ingested shellfish at a local restaurant 3 days back and other people who had food from that restaurant had similar symptoms. what is the most common cause of viral diarrhea in adult:
questions.solution: Ans. D Norovirus • Noroviruses are a common cause of gastroenteritis, especially in adults. They are a well-known cause of outbreaks of vomiting and diarrhea in hospitals, nursing homes, and on cruise ships. • It is transmitted by the fecal–oral route, often involving the ingestion of contaminated seafood or water. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 339

questions.text: The following diagram depicts blood smear of which species
questions.solution: Ans. A. P. vivax The diagnostic characters of P. vivax as follows Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 75

questions.text: A 24 year old female presented with an ulcer in the genital area. A Giemsa stained cervical smear was taken which showed the following. Image. identify the causative agent:
questions.solution: Ans: C. Calymmatobacteriumdonovanii • Calymmatobacterium (Donovania) granulomatis is the causative agent of granuloma inguinale, a granulomatous disease, which involves the genital and inguinal part of the infected host. • It is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis (formerly known as Calymmatobacteriumgranulomatis)characterized by genital ulcers. • It is also known as donovanosis, granuloma genitoinguinale, granuloma inguinaletropicum, granuloma venereum. • Specimen is collected by scraping the border of the ulcerative lesion and making a smear on a glass slide. • The smears are stained with Giemsa or Wright stains. • In the stained smear, the body of the bacillus is stained blue and the capsule is stained pink. • Tetracyclines, erythromycin, and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are effective for treatment of the condition. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No :219

questions.text: A smear was prepared from the genital ulcer identify the organism responsible: (color fig.)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Trichomonas vaginalis • Trichomonas occurs only in trophozoite form, which is pear­shaped, with 5 flagella and an undulating membrane. • The motility is rapid jerky or twitching type. • Habitat: Vagina and cervix in female and urethra in males. • Clinical features: Often asymptomatic in males. In females, it leads to pruritic vaginitis with greenish yellow discharge, strawberry mucosa and dysuria. • Diagnosis: By wet mount microscopy of vaginal or urethral discharge, Culture (gold standard), PCR, and by demonstration of antigen in vaginal smear by ELISA. • Treatment: Metronidazole is the drug of choice and simultaneous treatment of both partners is recommended. Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 36

questions.text: Antibodydependentenhancement is implicated in the immune pathogenesis of which disease :
questions.solution: Ans. B dengue hemorrhagic fever • In the same patient on reinfection with another serotype of dengue virus, the virus antibody complexes are formed within a few days of second dengue infection. • This results in an increase in viral entry and replication of a higher number of mononuclear cells followed by the release of cytokines, vasoactive mediators, and few coagulants. • This phenomenon is called antibody-dependent enhancement and is responsible primarily for the disseminated intravascular coagulation seen in the • patients with dengue hemorrhagic fever. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 359

questions.text: A patient presents with progressive dyspnea . chest X ray revealed a cavitary lesion in lower lobe of right lung . The following histopathological appearance was seen of resection of the cavity . What is the most likely cause of this disease and the number of layer that can be seen in the wall of the parasite :
questions.solution: Ans. A. Echinococcus with 3 layer • Microscopic examination showed cyst wall consisted of 3 layers. • Pericyst or advential layer • Ectocyst or outer cuticular layer • Endocyst or germinal layer Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 130

questions.text: A 35 year old farmer presents with multiple discharging cervical sinuses . Which of these stainswill be useful for the diagnosis ? Where does this organism normally colonise in the body
questions.solution: Ans. A. Gram stain oropharynx • Actinomyces species are present as normal flora of the oral cavity and also in the lower gastrointestinal tract and female genital tract of human hosts. • Cervicofacial actinomycosis (MC), thoracic actinomycosis, and actinomycosis of the abdomen and pelvis. • The specimens include sputum, bronchial secretions and discharges, and infected tissues. All these specimens may contain large number of sulfur granules. • Intestinal Actinomyces – PAS & Gram stain are useful Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 194

questions.text: The following picture was seen in nasal biopsy from a patient with brain abscess. Identify theorganism seen and the stain used:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Nocardia gram stain • Nocardia are Gram-positive bacilli showing a branching, beaded, and filamentous form. • It causes secondary CNS infections. • The condition manifests as chronic meningitis or as manifestation of single or multiple abscesses in the brain. • CNS Nocardiosis presents as slow, progressing mass lesion and is found in 20–40% of disseminated nocardial infection. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 195

questions.text: Autoinfection can be caused by all of the following helminths except :
questions.solution: Ans. A. Ascarislumbricoides Autoinfection causing parasites are • Capillaria philippinensis • Cryptosporidium parvum • Hymenolepsis nana • Enterobius vermicularis • Strongyloides stercoralis • Taenia solium Easy to remember – Mnemonic – CHEST Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P-4

questions.text: Obligate intracellular parasite is :
questions.solution: Ans. B. Ehrlichiachaffeensis • Bartonella grows in artificial culture medium. • Tropheryma whippelii & Coxiella burnetti grows in an axenic culture medium • Ehrlichia chaffeensis is Obligate intracellular. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -6

questions.text: Transfusion associated malaria has a shorter incubation period because of presence in blood of :
questions.solution: Ans. a. Trophozoites • Transfusion Malaria - Blood transfusion can accidentallytransmit malaria, if the donor isinfected with malaria. • The parasites may remain viable in blood bank for 1–2weeks. As this condition is induced by direct infection ofred cells by the merozoites, pre-erythrocyticschizogonyand hypnozoites are absent. • Relapse does not occurand incubation period is short. • Difference between mosquito & transfusion transmitted malaria Ref: Paniker’s textbookof medical parasitology 7/e P- 77

questions.text: Helminth implicated in causing pernicious anemia is :
questions.solution: Ans. a.Diphyllobothriumlatum Ref: Paniker’s textbookof medical parasitology 7/e P- 77

It allow staphylococcus and candida to grow

questions.text: In which of the following ways is CLED medium better then MacConkey agar
questions.solution: Ans. D.It allow staphylococcus and candida to grow. All the other choices are the common properties of CLED & MacConkey agar. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -233

questions.text: A 23 year old female present with fever and altered sensorium for two days with the following rash on legs. her BP is 70/50 mm Hg and neck stiffness is present lumbar puncture reveals cloudy CSF with 4200 cells/ UL. Protein level 198 and glucose of 21 mg Dl. Which of the following correctly describes the organism causing the following condition :
questions.solution: Ans. B. Gram-Negative diplococcic, ferments glucose and maltose. • The image depicts rash with petechial haemorrhage due to meningococcemia. • Meningococci is Gram negative lens shaped diplococci. • It ferments glucose and maltose. • Oxidase and catalase positive Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -287

questions.text: A 26 year old male present with fever and headache for 3 days his BP is 90/60 mm Hg and examination revealed the following rash on the legs . What is the likely diagnosis :
questions.solution: Ans. A. Meningococcus • Please refer the discussion part of previous question. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -287

questions.text: Gram stain show most likely which organism:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Streptococcus pneumonia • Gram positive diplococci & Lanceolate /Flame shape suggestive of Streptococcus pneumoniae Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -222

questions.text: A 23 year old male present with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhoea of one week duration. The following colonoscopicbiopsy is diagnostic of infection with:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Amoebiasis • Demonstration of Trophozoites • Discreet ulcers with normal intervening mucosa • May show areas of colitis or inflammatory polyps Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P- 21

choices.text: Transmission is through ingestion of infected pork
Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans
The helminth causes a transient self-resolving infection in humans
Drug of choice for this condition is albendazole

questions.text: The following is the ovum of an helminth. What is true about the helminth:
questions.solution: Ans.B. Both adult and larval stages are seen in humans • The image shows egg of H. nana • Diagnosing features are Hexacanth egg with polar filaments. • No intermediate host, so both larva & adult worm seen in humans Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P- 135

choices.text: Filariformlarvae is infective form humans as shown in the diagram
Transmitted through contaminated food and water usually
Females of these species show parthenogenesis

questions.text: A 40 year HIV positive male patient comes with odynophagia and watery diarrhoea. An endoscopy reveals oesophageal and gastric candidiasis. A wet mount of the stool of the patient reveal following picture . What is true about this helminth.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Females of these species show parthenogenesis • This picture is rhabditiform larva which is diagnostic form. • Mode of transmission is skin penetration •Drug of choice is Ivermectin Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P- 163

questions.text: The following pap smear shows infestation by :
questions.solution: Correct Anwer (A) Actinomyces • Actinomyces appearing as balls of dark staining filamentous organisms. • These organisms are often seen in patients wearing IUCD. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -295

questions.text: In the following gram stained specimen, identify the bacteria seen?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Neisseria gonorrhoea • Gram Negative diplococci – Kidney shaped – Intracellular – Suggestive of Neisseria gonorrhoea Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P-281

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with fever and chills for 3 days. On examination he was found to have delayed skin pinch time and dry oral mucosa. A peripheral blood smear revealed the following picture. Identify the pathogen involved?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Plasmodium falciparum • The early ring form in the erythrocyte is very delicate and tiny, measuring only a sixth(1/6) of the red cell diameter. • Rings are often seen attached along the margin of the red cell, the so-called form appliqué oraccole. • Binucleate rings (double chromatin) are commonresembling stereo headphones in appearance. • Severalrings may be seen within a single erythrocyte. • In course of time, the rings become larger, about a third of the size of the red cell and may have 1 or 2 grains of pigment inits cytoplasm Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P-71

choices.text: They are sequestered in the spleen
Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood
Due to antigen- antibody reaction and removal
They are seen in mosquito blood

questions.text: Why are schizont and late trophozoite stages of plasmodium falciparum not seen in peripheral blood smear?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Due to adherence to the capillary endothelium, they are not seen in peripheral blood • The trophozoites usually disappear from peripheralcirculation after about 24 hours. By then, membraneprotuberances appear in erythrocyte’s surface, 12–15hours after cell invasion. • These knobs extrude a high molecular weight, antigenically variant strain-specificerythrocyte membrane adhesive protein, Pf MP1, thatmediates attachment to receptors on venular capillary endothelium, an event termed ‘cytoadherence’. • Severalvascular receptors have been identified of whichintracellular adhesion molecule (ICAM-1) is probablymost important in the brain, chondroitin sulfate B in theplacenta, and CD36 in most other organs. • The infected erythrocytes stick inside and eventuallyblock capillaries and venules. At the same stage, these P.falciparuminfected RBCs adhere to uninfected RBCs toform rosettes. The process of cytoadherence, resetting,and agglutination are central to pathogenesis offalciparum malaria. • They result in sequestration of RBCscontaining mature form of the parasite in vital organs like brain, kidney, heart, lungs, spleen, intestine, bone marrow,and placenta, where they interfere with microcirculatoryflow and metabolism and are responsible for many ofthe serious complications of falciparum malaria, such ascerebral malaria Ref: Paniker’stextbook of medical parasitology 7/e P- 71

questions.text: What is the most common clinical manifestation when larvae of Ascaris, hookworm and Strongyloides migrated through the body?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Pneumonitis • As larval stages travel through the body, they may cause visceral damage, peritonitis and inflammation, enlargement of the liver or spleen, and an inflammation of the lungs. Pulmonary manifestations take place during larval migration and may present as Loeffler's syndrome, a transient respiratory illness associated with blood eosinophilia and pulmonary infiltrates with radiographic shadowing. • Dermal reaction not present in Ascariasis. •Cough and pneumonitis may result as the larvae begin to break into the alveoli and travel up the trachea in Hook worm and Thread worm infestations. Ref: Paniker’s Textbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P-164

choices.text: Embryonated egg is the infectious stage for this worm
The adult worm usually lives in the small intestine
Triclabendazole is the drug of choice

questions.text: The following is an intestinal nematode’s image. Which of these are true about it?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Embryonated egg is the infectious stage for this worm Enterobiusvermicularis • The egg is colorless planoconvex shape and not bile-stained. • Floats in saturated salt solution. • The egg contains a tadpole-shaped coiled embryo, which is fully formed, but becomes infectious only 6hours after being deposited on the skin. • Natural host: Man • Infective form: Embryonated eggs • Mode of infection: Man acquires infection by ingesting embryonated eggs containing larva by means of Contaminated ¬ fingers -Autoinfection Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P-191

choices.text: Viral culture and isolation in C6/36 cell line
ELISA for antibody against Dengue virus

questions.text: In a suspected patient of dengue, all of these are acceptable investigations at day 3 of presentation except
questions.solution: Ans. D. ELISA for antibody against Dengue virus. • Reverse transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR)-based methods are available for rapid identification and serotyping of dengue virus inacute-phase serum, roughly during the period of fever. • Isolation of the virus is difficult. • The current favored approach is inoculation of a mosquito cell line with patient serum coupledwith nucleic acid assays to identify a recovered virus. • Serologic diagnosis is complicated by cross-reactivity ofIgG antibodies to heterologous flavivirus antigens. • A variety of methods are available; the most commonly used methods are envelope/membrane viral protein-specific capture IgM or IgG ELISA and the HI test. IgM antibodies develop withina few days of illness and peak in 10th day. • Neutralizing and hemagglutination inhibiting antibodies appear within a week after the onset ofdengue fever. • Analysis of paired acute and convalescent sera to show a significant rise in antibody titre is the most reliableevidence of an active dengue infection. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -553

questions.text: A patient with benign hypertrophy of prostate was admitted in the hospital for 3 weeks. He subsequently developed suspected catheter associated-urinary tract infection. The tip of the catheter was sent for culture and was grown on blood agar. After 24 hours, the blood agar shows the following appearance. What is the likely causative agent for the UTI?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Proteus mirabilis • Swarming in blood agar suggestive of Proteus mirabilis growth. It is associated with catheter related UTI & Stag Horn renal calculi. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -236

questions.text: Which of these is an Obligate intracellular pathogen?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Coxiella burnetti • Among the choices, best one is Coxiella burnetti. • Initially It was considered as an obligate intracellular pathogen and currently scientists derived an axenic medium for C. burnetti. Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -6

questions.text: A patient presented to the hospital with severe hydrophobia. You suspect rabies obtain corneal scrapings from the patient. What test should be done on this specimen for a diagnosis of Rabies?
questions.solution: Ans. A. RT- PCR for rabies virus RT PCR is the most sensitive test for the detection of Rabies virus. It is a rapid test for the presumptive diagnosis of the condition. Other options- IF and testing antibodies against rabies yields high false positive results. Negri bodies examination is done post-mortem.

questions.text: What Treponema is seen in the silver impregnation micrograph below:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Leptospira interrogans Leptospira are tightly coiled, thin, flexible spirochetes 5–15 μm long, with very fine spirals 0.1–0.2 μm wide; one end is oftenbent, forming a hook. They are actively motile, which is bestseen using a dark-field microscope. Electron micrographsshow a thin axial filament and a delicate membrane. The spirochete is so delicate that in the dark-field view, it may appearonly as a chain of minute cocci. It does not stain readily but can be impregnated with silver – Fontana stain &Levaditi stain Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -330

questions.text: Which of the following parasite’s life cycle is shown below?
questions.solution: Ans. B. Fasciola hepatica • The above picture is the life cycle of Fasciola hepatica • Fasciola hepatica - Sheep liver fluke comes under Trematodes/flukes • Adult worms reside in the biliary passages of the liver of sheep, goat and Human • Eggs are large, elliptical, operculate, light-yellowish brown coloured. • Infective form is Metacercariae encysted on water plants and mode of transmission is ingestion. • First Intermediate host: Snails &Second intermediate host: Aquatic vegetations • Infection: Fascioliasis • Lab diagnosis: Detection of operculated eggs in stool or in bile obtained by duodenal intubation • Treatment: Bithionol, Triclabendazole and dehydroemetine. Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P- 152

questions.text: Which of the following fits to the life cycle picture given below
questions.solution: Ans. A. E. histolytica • Entamoebahistolytica: Three morphological forms available – Trophozoite, Pre-cyst &cyst • Trophozoites reside in mucosa and submucosa of large intestine of man. • Trophozoites are the only form present in tissues; it has ingested red blood cells, leucocytes and tissue debris within the endoplasm and actively motile with pseudopodium. • Cyst: Spherical with quadri-nucleus and rounded chromatid bars. Mature quadrinucleate cysts are infective form to humans. • Lab diagnosis: Wet saline mount, stained preparations, IHA, IFA, ELISA; Histology; Molecular methods like PCR. Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P-17

questions.text: The below picture shows egg of
questions.solution: Ans. A. A. duodenale • Ancylostoma duodenale – old world hookworm • Adult worm lives in the small intestine of man • Eggs: Eggs are oval or elliptical in shape; colourless – non-bile stained; surrounded by a thin transparent hyaline shell; has a segmented ovum with four blastomeres. Ref: Paniker’sTextbook of Medical Parasitology 7/e P- 184

questions.text: The following is a picture from scrapping of genital ulcer. Your diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. A. Klebsiellagranulomatis • The three major genital ulcer diseases are syphilis, Herpes, and Chancroid • H. ducreyi – chancroid (soft chancre) – School of fish appearance. • Neisseria - Gram negative kidney shaped diplococci - mostly intracellular. • Genital ulcer - Gram-negative rods with macrophage - surrounded by neutrophils denotes Klebsiella granulomatis Ref: Jawetz, Melnick, &Adelberg’s Medical Microbiology, 27/e, P -794

choices.text: 1 Fab and one hyper variable region

questions.text: Papain cleaves the immunoglobulin molecule into
questions.solution: Ans. A. 1 Fc and 2 Fab fragments • Antibody molecule when treated with proteolytic enzyme like papain cleaves the molecule into two Fab fragments and 1 Fc fragment • Above the hinge region is broken Ref. Levinson, Review of medical microbiology – 14/e Pg : 525

questions.text: Identify the below organism
questions.solution: Ans. a. Nocardia sp • The above picture denotes acid fast filamentous bacteria suggestive of Nocardia asteroids • It is Gram-positive bacteria with branching filaments & causes pulmonary nocardiasis in immunocompromised individuals. • Weakly acid fast – with 1% (in tissues) & 0.5 % (fluids) H2SO4 Ref. Levinson, Review of medical microbiology – 14/e P-195

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infection is not toxin mediated?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Septicaemia • S. aureus produces many toxins like TSST, Exfoliative toxin, Enterotoxin. • Except septicaemia, all other choices are exotoxin mediated. • Diseases caused by staphylococcus aureus. Ref. Levinson, Review of medical microbiology – 13/e P-256

questions.text: A 20-Years-old male with history of fever and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mononucleosis and was ordered a Paul Bunnel test. Which of the following is the principle of the test?
questions.solution: Ans. A. Heterophile antibody test Paul –Bunnell Test Heterophile antibody tests Antibody produced against EBV, cross reacts with Sheep RBC. Paul-Bunnell or Monospot tests - used in the diagnosis of glandular fever. IgMheterophil antibodies are usually detectable for the first 3 months of infection. Ref: Murray’s Medical Microbiology, 8/e, P -437

questions.text: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to
questions.solution: Ans. C. Aquatic protistan protozoa • Currently Rhinosporidumseeberi is classified under- DRIP clade of protistan parasites (hydrophilic organism) – aquatic protozoa • Direct inoculation skin or mucosa – contaminated stagnant water source • Common sites are Nose, nasopharynx • Red polyps – sessile or pedunculated Ref: Murray’s Medical Microbiology, 8/e, P -669

questions.text: The picture below depicts a bacterium which is most consistent with:

questions.text: The (1,3)-ß-B-Glucanpanfungal detection assay is useful in the diagnosis of which ONE of the following infection?

questions.text: Which bacterium best exemplifies the information provided in the image?

Leptospiraicterohaemorrhagiae • Spirochetes are motile bacteria but without any external flagella. • They are motile due to the presence of an axial filament. • Axial filament consists of a bundle of flagellum-like structures that lie between the cell surface and an outer sheath, and connects one end of the cell to the other. • They are sometimes called the endoflagellates Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 199

questions.text: The replication cycle of a virus is depicted below, Identify the virus?
questions.solution: Ans: B. Hepatitis B virus • The replicative cycle of HBV • After entry of the virion into the cell and its uncoating, the nucleocapsid moves to the nucleus. • In the nucleus, the virion DNA polymerase synthesizes the missing portion of DNA, and a double-stranded circular DNA is formed. • This DNA serves as a template for mRNA synthesis by cellular RNA polymerase. • After the individual mRNAs are made, a full-length positive-strand RNA is made, which is the template for the minus strand of the progeny DNA. • The minus strand then serves as the template for the plus strand of the genome DNA. • This RNA-dependent DNA synthesis catalyzed by reverse transcriptase encoded by HBV takes place within the newly assembled virion nucleocapsid core in the cytoplasm. • The RNA-dependent DNA synthesis that produces the genome and the DNA- dependent DNA synthesis that fills in the missing portion of DNA soon after infection of the next cell are carried out by the same enzyme Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 345

questions.text: The plasmodium species known for relapse in malaria is

Ref: Panicker’s Text book of Parasitology, 7th Ed, Pg. No: 66

During 2012–2015, several outbreaks and cases of CCHF transmitted by ticks via livestock and several nosocomial infections were reported in the states of Gujarat and Rajasthan. • A CCHF case was also reported from Uttar Pradesh state. questions.text: A Female had a thorn prick 5 years ago. She presented with a slowly growing 2x2 cm verrucous lesion which on KOH mount showed the following image

Chromoblastomycosis • This is a slowly progressive granulomatous infection that is caused by several soil fungi (Fonsecaea, Phialophora, Cladosporium, etc.) when introduced into the skin through trauma. • These fungi are collectively called dematiaceous fungi, so named because their conidia or hyphae are dark- colored, either gray or black. • Wart-like lesions with crusting abscesses extend along the lymphatics. • In the clinical laboratory, demonstration of dark brown, round fungal cells – Copper penny bodies/Medler bodies are pathognomic. • The disease is treated with oral flucytosine or thiabendazole, plus local surgery. questions.text: A 47-years-old hospitalized man who has received multiple antibiotics in the last 10 days develops diarrhea. A fecal sample is sent to the laboratory. Which of the following test is used to establish Clostridium difficile as a causative agent of diarrhea?
questions.solution: Ans.B. PCR for toxin genes PCR for toxin gene detection in stool is very sensitive and specific for diagnosis of clostridium difficile diarrhea. • The presence of exotoxins in the filtrate of a patient’s stool specimen is the basis of the laboratory diagnosis. • It is insufficient to culture the stool for the presence of C. difficile because people can be colonized by the organism and not have disease. • There are two types of tests used to make the laboratory diagnosis. One detects the exotoxin itself and the other detects the genes that encode the exotoxin. • To detect the exotoxin itself, an ELISA test employing antibody to the exotoxin is used. • To detect the genes that encode the exotoxin, a PCR assay to determine the presence of the toxin gene DNA is used. • The DNA-based test has greater sensitivity and specificity than the ELISA test. • However, these NAAT tests (nucleic acid amplification tests) should be interpreted with caution because a person may only be colonized by C. difficile and be recorded as positive when in fact, C. difficile is not the cause of the patient’s disease. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 142

questions.text: All of these properties can be attributed to biofilms except:
questions.solution: Ans. B. Adherence to a structure Biofilm does not lead to the property of adherence. Affected microbial metabolism, extracellular virulence factors produced, and decreased susceptibility to biocides, antimicrobial agents, and host defence molecules and cells are all effects of biofilm growth. • After the bacteria attach, they often form a protective matrix called a biofilm consisting of various polysaccharides and proteins. • Biofilms form especially on foreign bodies such as prosthetic joints, prosthetic heart valves, and intravenous catheters, but they also form on native structures such as heart valves. • Biofilms protect bacteria from both antibiotics and host immune defenses such as antibodies and neutrophils. • They also retard wound healing resulting in chronic wound infections, especially in diabetics. Ref: Review of Medical Microbiology and Immunology, Warren Levinson, 14th Ed, Page No : 37

questions.text: True about Campylobacter jejuni:
questions.solution: Ans. B Under light microscopy, C. jejuni has a characteristic "sea-gull" shape as a consequence of its helical form. Campylobacter is grown on specially selective "CAMP" agar plates at 42 °C, the normal avian body temperature, rather than at 37 °C, the temperature at which most other pathogenic bacteria are grown. Since the colonies are oxidase positive, they usually only grow in scanty amounts on the plates. Microaerophilic conditions are required for luxurious growth. A selective blood agar medium (Skirrow's medium) can be used. Greater selectivity can be gained with an infusion of a cocktail of antibiotics: vancomycin, polymixin-B, trimethoprim, and actidione ([Preston's agar]),and growth under microaerophilic conditions at 42 °C.

questions.text: Shigella like diarrhoea is caused by:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Enteroinvasive E. coli – Shigella-like dysentery Enteroinvasive E. coli (EIEC) causes a form of diarrhea that closely resembles Shigella infection, both clinically and pathogenetically. EIEC invades and destroys colonic epithelial cells, leading to bloody diarrhea, abdominal cramps, and fever, mimicking dysentery. Like Shigella, EIEC is non-lactose fermenting and non-motile in culture and shares similar virulence mechanisms such as intracellular spread. Why the Other Options Are Incorrect: A. Enteroaggregative E. coli (EAEC) EAEC is typically associated with persistent diarrhea, especially in children and HIV-positive patients. It does not invade mucosa, and diarrhea is generally non-bloody, making it unlike Shigella. B. Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC) ETEC is the most common cause of traveler’s diarrhea and produces heat-labile and/or heat-stable toxins, leading to watery, non-bloody diarrhea. It does not cause mucosal invasion, so it does not mimic Shigella. D. Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) EHEC (especially strain O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea and is associated with Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS), but unlike Shigella, it does not invade epithelial cells. It releases Shiga-like toxins that cause vascular damage, not direct mucosal destruction.

questions.text: Neisseria vaccine (MCV-4 and MPSV-4) strains are not protective against:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) B. The quadrivalent meningococcal vaccines, MCV-4 (conjugate) and MPSV-4 (polysaccharide), are formulated to provide protection against Neisseria meningitidis serogroups A, C, W-135, and Y. They are not effective against serogroup B. Why Serogroup B is Different The polysaccharide capsule of serogroup B is chemically similar to human nervous system tissues, which means it is poorly immunogenic and does not trigger a strong protective immune response from the body. Because of this, a different type of vaccine had to be developed to combat serogroup B. These new vaccines, known as MenB vaccines (e.g., Bexsero and Trumenba), use a different technology, such as recombinant proteins or outer membrane vesicles, to elicit an immune response.

questions.text: Which is true about bacterial resistance?
questions.solution: Answer: D types of bacterial resistence 1. Drug inactivation or modification: for example, enzymatic deactivation of penicillin G in some penicillin-resistant bacteria through the production of ?-lactamases. Most commonly, the protective enzymes produced by the bacterial cell will add an acetyl or phosphate group to a specific site on the antibiotic, which will reduce its ability to bind to the bacterial ribosomes and disrupt protein synthesis. 2. Alteration of target- or binding site: for example, alteration of PBP—the binding target site of penicillins—in MRSA and other penicillin-resistant bacteria. Another protective mechanism found among bacterial species is ribosomal protection proteins. These proteins protect the bacterial cell from antibiotics that target the cell's ribosomes to inhibit protein synthesis. The mechanism involves the binding of the ribosomal protection proteins to the ribosomes of the bacterial cell, which in turn changes its conformational shape. This allows the ribosomes to continue synthesizing proteins essential to the cell while preventing antibiotics from binding to the ribosome to inhibit protein synthesis. 3. Alteration of metabolic pathway: for example, some sulfonamide-resistant bacteria do not require para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA), an important precursor for the synthesis of folic acid and nucleic acids in bacteria inhibited by sulfonamides, instead, like mammalian cells, they turn to using preformed folic acid. 4. Reduced drug accumulation: by decreasing drug permeability or increasing active efflux (pumping out) of the drugs across the cell surface. These pumps within the cellular membrane of certain bacterial species are used to pump antibiotics out of the cell before they are able to do any damage. They are often activated by a specific substrate associated with an antibiotic as in fluoroquinolone resistance. 5. Ribosome splitting and recycling: for example, drug-mediated stalling of the ribosome by lincomycin and erythromycin unstalled by a heat shock protein found in Listeria monocytogenes, which is an homologous of HflX from other bacteria. Liberation of the ribosome from the drug allows further translation and consequent resistance to the drug.

questions.text: Haemorrhagic fever is caused by?
questions.solution: Ans: A, B, C, D Ref: Harrison 19th Ed/1319-24 Explanation: Viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF) is a constellation of findings based on vascular instability anddecreased vascular integrity. An assault, direct or indirect, on themicrovasculature leads to increased permeability and (particularlywhen platelet function is decreased) to actual disruption and localhemorrhage (a positive tourniquet sign). Blood pressure is decreased,and in severe cases shock supervenes. Cutaneous flushing and conjunctivalsuffusion are examples of common, observable abnormalitiesin the control of local circulation. Hemorrhage occurs infrequently. The common causative agents include a) Arenaviruses: The most important arenaviruses causing VHF areJunin virus, Lassa virus, and Machupo virus. b) Bunyaviruses: The most important VHF-causing bunyaviruses areCrimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever virus, hantaviruses, Rift Valleyfever virus, and “severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome virus. c) Flaviviruses: The most important flaviviruses that cause VHF are themosquito-borne dengue viruses 1–4, yellow fever viruses, Kyasanur Forest disease virus and Omsk hemorrhagicfever virus.

questions.text: Cause(s) of immunodeficiency associated with neutropenia is/are?
questions.solution: Ans: A, B, C, D • Chediak higashi syndrome: it is a rare autosomal recessive syndrome. There is a defect/ mutation in LYST gene (lysosomal trafficking regulator) . patients has recurrent bacterial infections, defects in blood clotting, pigmentation and neurologic dysfunction, neutropenia, oculocutaneous albinism. There is impairment in the function of T cells, NK cells and granulocytes. • Pearson syndrome: rare disorder in which bone marrow fails to produce neutrophils. It also presents with pancytopenia. It is a mitochondrial disease due to defective mitochondrial DNA. Other abnormalities found are: pancreatic fibrosis, insulin dependent diabetes, exocrine pancreatic dysfunction, defective muscle function, sideroblastic anaemia and neurological infection. The child dies after birth due to failure to thrive • Chronic idiopathic neutropenia: it is predominantly seen in females. Blood neutrophil count is less than 1.5 x 109 /L. bone marrow examination shows modest decrease in metamyelocytes and neutrophils. If count falls less than 0.5x 109 /ll, it results in fever and minor infections which should be treated by administering G-CSF. • Kostmann syndrome: it is a congenital form of neutropenia, which manifests early in infancy with life threatening bacterial infections. Treatment is with filgrastim (G-CSF)

Most common nerve roots involved are T3-L3. Peak appearance is in 6th decade. It shows a feature of post herpitic neuralgia ie persistent pain even after the disappearance of rashes.

questions.text: All of the following cause direct transmission of disease except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Droplet nuclei Droplet nuclei are tiny respiratory particles, usually less than 5 micrometers in size, that remain suspended in the air for long periods. They are produced when an infected person coughs, sneezes, or talks, and they can travel considerable distances before being inhaled by another person. Because they remain airborne and do not require close physical contact between the source and the new host, they are classified as an indirect mode of transmission. In contrast, direct transmission requires immediate transfer of the pathogen without an intermediary, such as through touching, kissing, sexual contact, or vertical transmission from mother to child. Diseases like tuberculosis, measles, and varicella spread through droplet nuclei, which explains their high infectivity. This mechanism differs from large respiratory droplets, which settle quickly and usually require close proximity. Thus, saying that droplet nuclei cause direct transmission is incorrect.

questions.text: Flask shaped ulcers in the intestine are caused by
questions.solution: Ans: B Entamoeba histolytica are the pathogenic species of amoeba. It causes amoebic dysentery and flask shaped ulcers/ water bittle ulcers which have narrow muth and wide base. It causes ameobiasis among which 95% are intestinal forms and 5% is extraintestinal/ invasive amoebiasis. Most common site for intestinal amoebiasis is ileoceacal region, second most common site is sigmoid colon. Most common site for extra intestinal amoebiasis is right lobe of liver.

questions.text: Contact isolation is done for

questions.text: Coxsackie A16 virus causes which of the following conditions?
questions.solution: Ans: B Hand- foot-mouth disease • Incubation period: 4 to 6 days • Followed by fever, anoxeria and malaise • Specific features: sore throat, vesicles on buccal mucosa and tongue. Followed by vesicles on dorsum of hands • 100% attack rate in kids. Self resolving disease.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Pneumocystis jiroveci?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A. Associated with CMV False. While both can occur in immunocompromised patients, especially those with HIV/AIDS, Pneumocystis jiroveci and CMV are not directly associated. They may co-occur, but one doesn't cause or require the other. B. Diagnosis is by sputum microscopy Partially true, but not the most accurate method. Induced sputum can sometimes help, but bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is more sensitive and preferred for diagnosis. So this is not the best answer. C. Seen only in immunocompromised patients True. Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (PJP) primarily affects immunocompromised individuals – like those with HIV/AIDS, transplant recipients, or those on immunosuppressive therapy. It is rare in immunocompetent people. D. Always associated with pneumatocele False. Pneumatoceles can occur in some cases, especially in children, but they are not always present and not a defining feature

questions.text: All are true about congenital toxoplasmosis except?

Person who acquires microorganism from another carrier

questions.text: Paradoxical carriers are
questions.solution: Ans: B • Contact carrier: Person who acquires the microorganism due to his contact with the patient • Convalescent carrier: Person who has clinically recovered from an infectious disease and now is still capable of transmitting the infectious agent to others • Paradoxical carrier: Person who acquires microorganism from another carrier
